repnme.cdata!:
China - First and Second Ertan
            Hydroelectric Projects, Sichuan Power Transmission Project,
            and Zhejiang Power Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings for the First and Second
            Ertan Hydroelectric Projects, Sichuan Power Transmission
            Project, and Zhejiang Power Development Project for China
            are as follows: For each of the four projects, the project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is high; Bank performance
            is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is satisfactory.
            The experience gained under the three projects reviewed in
            this report, as well as from the pursuit o f concurrent
            power sector reforms at the national level in China, offers
            these general lessons: 1) Power shortages are a barrier to
            the pursuit of market reforms aimed at increasing
            competition. 2)  Effective regulatory arrangements should be
            in place at the same time (if not sooner) as power supply
            entities are unbundled, in order to reduce abuses of market
            power. 3)  Indicative power system planning at the national
            level is essential in order to avoid boom-bust investment
            cycles such as the one currently building up in the Chinese
            power sector.

            I/CFS CONL'T

abstracts.cdata!:
Impressive ratings convey a highly
            satisfactory project outcome, highly likely sustainability,
            and high institutional development impacts, accomplished by
            highly satisfactory performances by both the Bank and
            Borrower. The lessons drawn from this specific project
            suggest, and reinforce that reforms in the industry
            structure, and market organization require strong commitment
            by the central government, whereas commitment by provincial
            governments, and public participation are key to successful
            environmental management, and population resettlement,
            contributors to the project success. Nonetheless,
            participation of lawyers in the preparation of bidding
            documents, contract negotiation and implementation is
            crucial, specifically, as legal support for claims against
            steam turbine suppliers arose, requiring precious time and
            resources due to lack of legal advice in drafting
            procurement terms and conditions. And unfortunately,
            technology transfer may become risky: despite excellent
            references, the manufacturer of boilers fostered costly
            delays, by improvising design options that proved
            unsatisfactory. Pre-qualification specifications should
            require proven references for equipment supply, not just a
            general experience. In addition, inexperience of the
            supplier for the coal conveying/feeding system caused
            suspension of contract execution and major delays. It is
            thus suggested that prompt government clearances be
            introduced, while similarly, effective design management
            could ensure a timely delivery of engineering designs.

repnme.cdata!:
Guarantees improve terms of China's
            private borrowing : The Yangzhou and Zhejiang Thermal Power Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The Yangzhou and Zhejiang Thermal Power
            Projects involve construction of large, coal-fired thermal
            power plants and expansion of related transmission networks,
            and represent a major expansion in the generating capacity
            of their respective provinces (about 15 percent in Jiangsu
            and 27 percent in Zhejiang). Partial credit guarantees were
            used for both projects. The partial credit guarantee covers
            a portion of a financing against all risks. This contrasts
            with the partial risk guarantee, which can cover up to the
            entire amount of a financing against specific risks. The
            guarantees were structured to extend the maturity of
            commercial loans and provide China with greater flexibility
            in accessing world financial markets, e.g., interest rate
            (fixed or floating) and currency (to match procurement
            contracts). At the same time, the Government and Bank wished
            to minimize their exposure under the guarantee. This report
            discusses the borrowing terms and guarantee structure for
            each project and their respective costs and benefits.
